about.title: About
about.imageAlt: Portrait of Emil Maria Ertl leaning against a wall
paragraphs: Emil Maria Ertl (they/them), *94 in Nürnberg, works as a dancer, choreographer and facilitator in the field of performance art. Both in their own work as well as when collaborating, their main curiosity lies in social relationality and its navigation. When making dance, Emil is interested in porosity, choreography as a container for feelings, holding several perspectives at once, staying with friction, moving within paradoxes, and magic-making.
Emil’s work *Eternal Betrayal* was shown at Ballhaus Ost in the frame of Dirty Debüt, and at ada studios in the frame of NAH DRAN extended.
As a dancer they work with choreographers such as Ligia Lewis, Anan Fries, Olympia Bukkakis, Anna Lublina, Gry Tingskog, Ellen Söderhult and Ar Utke Acs.
Emil is facilitating dance workshops both in community-centers as well as in institutions.

They studied at Tanzfabrik Berlin, Hochschule für Musik und Tanz Köln and graduated from University of the Arts Stockholm in 2019 with a Bachelor in Dance Performance. In 2023, Emil received the danceWEB scholarship at Impulstanz Vienna.
Emil is based in Berlin and active in Germany, Sweden and internationally.

works.title: Serpentine Serpentine
details: Serpentine serpentine never a straight line serpentine.

Along the lines of Peaches’ song Serpentine, this research investigates the notion of creases, crumples, wrinkles and folds. Straightened things appear to function, to be correct, to be clean. Wrinkled or crumpled stuff on the other hand commonly is thought of as messy, wild or inappropriate. Serpentine Serpentine wishes to dissect this dichotomy and examine the potential of the act of crumpling. If the act of straightening stands for heteronormativity, can the act of crumpling be a queer act of resistance? How can we use choreography as a tool to research the act of straightening things out?
Concept: Onur Agbaba and Emil Ertl

works.title: Eigentümliche Verhältnisse
details: Through performative interventions, this research in essay-film format aims to reveal invisible boundaries of property relations and investigates affects coupled to them. Using the notion of property domination as a world relationship (Sachherrschaft als Weltverhältnis), Eigentümliche Verhältnisse seeks to challenge the manifestation of property relations and the sacredness of private property.
Concept, Camera, Choreography: Onur Agbaba, Lotta Beckers, Emil Ertl
Song: I’m a Victim of this Song – Pipilotti Rist
Fonds DAKU Recherche Förderung HAU Berlin, 2022

works.title: Eternal Betrayal
works.imageAlt: Two performers during Eternal Betrayal embracing
details: Eternal Betrayal is a collection of various movie scenes that all portray the same thing: a revelation of a betrayal. In film plots, these scenes classically are followed by relief and reharmonization – a narration through which societal morals are revealed. Those morals often point towards heteronormative, cis-patriarchal ideas of order and loyalty. Driven by the desire to stay with brokenness instead of seeking moralist glue to fix it with, Eternal Betrayal invites to soak in your tears and linger within the clarity of (heart)break.
Dirty Debüt, Ballhaus Ost Berlin + NAH DRAN extended, ada studios Berlin 2021

works.title: Outro – riding solo with u
works.imageAlt: Emil Ertl dancing in Outro – riding solo with u
details: Outro – riding solo with u is a performance made for two and danced by one. Besides dealing with relationality and long distance intimacies, this dance moves within the space between what is lost and what remains when grieving. Outro – riding solo with u can be thought of as a continuation of Eternal Betrayal.
Concept, Choreography, Performance, Sound: Emil Ertl
Broken Knee Festival at Ackerstadtpalast Berlin

facilitating.imageAlt: Emil Ertl teaching a group in a dance studio
paragraphs: Emil is facilitating dance workshops both in institutions as well as community-oriented organizations.

The content of their classes varies from each occasion and are puzzled together with improvisation techniques, movement research, commercial jazz dance, instant composition practices and a good sprinkle of 90s pop music.

© Emil Maria Ertl 2023
c/o Studio13 e.V.
Ziegrastraße 13
12057 Berlin
amertl.mails[at]gmail.com
Webdesign and Programming: Paul Dombrowski
